We have not been in direct combat with the Taliban since 2014. That's eight years ago. It was seven years when the president made that decision. That was a completely false narrative that he presented to the American people. That wasn't the choice. And the fact that all the Europeans who were in Afghanistan had 6,000 troops there, that they wanted to stay, was very telling, because they're only making a decision because it's in their national interest, it's in their interest to protect their own people. And we gave it all up and we're back to where we were in 2001.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: Now, if you talk to administration sources, national security sources, which I did yesterday, they tell you that number one, outside investigators have proven that the attack at Abbey Gate where we lost American blood and treasure could not have been prevented. They also say, look, we evacuated safely about 125,000 people. A lot of those people were relocated to the United States, into our allied countries. We help them get medical treatment. The U.S. military has never conducted an evacuation successfully on that scale before. What do you say to that?

utterances.speaker: KEANE
utterances.utterance: Well, we're talking about an emergency evacuation that could have been prevented by the president's decision if he had made -- if he took the advice of his counsels and advisors. And certainly, it was very tragic that we lost those soldiers going out. We le -- we have left 80,000 people behind who still want to get out who we recognize as being partners of the United States, and they overshadow this thing certainly. But, listen, let's go back to this point about security at the airport.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: Uh-huh.

utterances.speaker: KEANE
utterances.utterance: The Taliban and the United States military negotiated about security. The Taliban offered to the United States military the opportunity to have control of Kabul and they would not be involved in the inner city of itself. We rejected that. And obviously, that would have been a little bit more than we were intending to bite off in doing that, but it would have given us the opportunity to conduct a very methodical withdrawal as opposed to this chaos that we saw, and the Taliban -- and keep the Taliban away from the airport completely so we could vet the people more orderly who were evacuating. That would have prevented the tragedy that we had at the end, and also the follow-up tragedy that we got involved in killing the innocent family when we thought that they were terrorists.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: So, FOX News learned exclusively yesterday that the DOD and State Department are nearing completion of their own after-action review a year later of what happened during the withdrawal. They're going to send that to the National Security Council in a few days, as early as this coming week. What do you think is going to be in that report?

utterances.speaker: KEANE
utterances.utterance: Well, I hope it covers everything, not just the withdrawal, because the U.S. policy decisions for 20 years, many of it on the Republican and Democratic administrations, was misguided. And it got us to a point where the only thing that was acceptable to us was to stalemate. And if we go back and trace those policy decisions, I think we should be honest with ourselves of which ones were misguided and why it put us in such a difficult situation in Afghanistan after 20 years. Certainly, a focus on the withdrawal needs to be done because we lost our troops and -- as a result of that. And hopefully, we'll get some -- get some positive answers and more importantly, let's learn some lessons here about these decisions in terms of going forward, and let's be honest with what took place and the mistakes that were made.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: General, thanks so much for your time.

utterances.speaker: KEANE
utterances.utterance: Yeah, great talking to you, Gillian.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: We really appreciate it. Great to talk to you. Well, up next, John Fetterman returns to the campaign trail now after being sidelined by a stroke. What this means for the highest stakes Pennsylvania Senate race. Plus, we're on the road to the midterms with a look at what's on the ballot in a wild Alaska.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: FOX NEWS SUNDAY is on the road to the midterms in Alaska where voters are navigating a whole new voting system ahead of Tuesday's primary. Jonathan Hunt reports for us from Anchorage.

utterances.speaker: SEN. LISA MURKOWSKI (R-AK)
utterances.utterance: We're going to get everybody riled and ready.

utterances.speaker: JONATHAN HUNT, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT (voice over)
utterances.utterance: Senator Lisa Murkowski knows she's in a fight. After 20 years in the Senate, she is facing perhaps her strongest election threat yet.

utterances.speaker: KELLY TSHIBAKA (R), ALASKA SENATE CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: Thank you. Well, I appreciate your vote. I'm Kelly.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.utterance: Kelly Tshibaka running significant to the right of the more moderate Murkowski is pushing hard.

utterances.speaker: TSHIBAKA
utterances.utterance: You can either vote for the senator the Joe Biden wants to be the next senator of Alaska, his best friend, Lisa Murkowski, or we're going to vote for the senator that represent Alaska values.

utterances.speaker: MURKOWSKI
utterances.utterance: I'm the senator that will represent all of Alaska, Rural and urban, men and women, Alaska natives, individuals that have just come to our state.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: Kelly, please come up. Kelly.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.utterance: Tshibaka as the enthusiastic backing of former President Trump, who campaigned for her here just last month while making clear his view of Senator Murkowski, who voted to impeach Trump after the January 6th riots.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Lisa Murkowski, she is the worst.

utterances.speaker: MURKOWSKI
utterances.utterance: Former President Trump is going to say what he will say.

utterances.speaker: HUNT (on camera)
utterances.utterance: Would you prefer he remained a former president rather than a future president?

utterances.speaker: MURKOWSKI
utterances.utterance: I would. The problem that we have is that Donald Trump, when he was in office, failed to uphold the Constitution of the United States. For me, it's pretty simple.

utterances.speaker: HUNT (voice over)
utterances.utterance: Alaska voters will also have to decide if they want another Trump-backed candidate, former Governor Sarah Palin, to represent them in the House of Representatives. Palin fighting fellow Republican Nick Begich, and Democrat, Mary Peltola, in a special election to fill the House seat left vacant by the death this year of Congressman Don Young. And Trump-backed Republican Governor Mike Dunleavy is hoping to become the first incumbent Alaska governor to win a second term in nearly a quarter of a century.

utterances.speaker: GOV. MIKE DUNLEAVY (R-AK)
utterances.utterance: That's the goal. That's - that's the focus. And really it's not just breaking the streak, obviously, but it's continuing the work that we've been doing here. Again, we feel Alaska's in better shape today than it was when we inherited.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.utterance: But it is the Senate race that is being most closely watched here.

utterances.speaker: HUNT (on camera)
utterances.utterance: Can you win? Really, do believe you can win?

utterances.speaker: TSHIBAKA
utterances.utterance: Oh, I absolutely believe I can win.

utterances.speaker: HUNT (voice over)
utterances.utterance: The truth is, both Tshibaka and Murkowski will likely make it through the primary because of Alaska's new voting method which sends the top four vote getters through to the general regardless of party. But Tuesday's finishing order will be critical in terms of momentum heading to November and will tell us a lot about whether the power of a Trump endorsement can hold sway even in one of the most fiercely independent states in the nation.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: Jonathan Hunt reporting from Anchorage for us. Thank you. We're back now with the Sunday panel. So, Susan, Alaska, we just saw, Sarah Palin's been keeping a low profile, shall we say, ahead of Tuesday, only doing a couple of public events. Is she counting on her Trump endorsement and maybe her celebrity to carrier her across the finish line, or is she really kind of banking on her campaign fizzling out?

utterances.speaker: PAGE
utterances.utterance: Well, I think she has universal name recognition. People from Alaska and across the country know who Sarah Palin is. If Alaska had not gone to ranked choice voting, she might very well be in a position to win this special election on Tuesday. But now, unless she can get a majority of the vote, it goes into another round, and that gives the prospect that that hard core of support that she has from Alaska will not be enough to get her over the finish line. We'll see if there's a second act in American politics for Sarah Palin.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: Marie, let's talk about Dems prospects for holding on to the Senate. In Pennsylvania and Wisconsin, they've put up Mandela Barnes and John Fetterman, both progressives, obviously, hoping to flip seats from red to blue. "Politico" says, quote, the rise of Barnes and Fetterman is an opportunity for the left-wing of the party, which has often struggled to flip swing states - swing seats and instead found success in ousting Democratic incumbents in deep blue areas. Now, Fetterman returned to the campaign trail Friday for the first time since having a stroke in May. So, are we seeing a leftward shift in the party here? And, if so, what does that, you know, spell for moderates and independents?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Well, I think each state had primaries. In a state like Pennsylvania, John Fetterman won for a number of reasons, including the fact that he's pretty authentic, right? Maybe more so than some of the other candidates in that primary. But what Democrats will tell you, Gillian, is that every time the Republicans nominate a far right 2020 election, you know, questioning an extreme Trump backed candidate, whether it's in Arizona or Pennsylvania or Ohio or any of the - you know, or Ron Johnson in Wisconsin, who's, of course, an incumbent, Democrats feel better and better about their chances. We now have, on the generic congressional ballot for the House, Democrats have caught up to Republicans. For months they've been down. They've now caught up to them. So, yes, there are progressives running in these states, but the Democrat - the Republican candidates are so far to the right, they're so extreme on everything from election integrity and their denial of the 2020 outcome, saying they won't certify in the future, where they are on abortion in a post-Roe overturned world. So, look, I think Democrats are feeling bullish today about their chances across the country, but particularly in the Senate.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: Jason, you just heard Senator Murkowski tell Jonathan Hunt there that she hopes former President Trump remains the former president. Here's another candidate emphasizing the daylight between himself and Trump. Listen. BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS HOST, "SPECIAL REPORT": You've said perhaps President Trump shouldn't run again in the past. What are your thoughts now in the wake of this raid?

utterances.speaker: JOE O'DEA (R), COLORADO U.S. SENATE CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: Look, I came out and I was vocal. I don't think he should run for president. We've got a lot of very talented people on the bench. I like Ron DeSantis. I like Tim Scott, Nikki Haley. There's a lot of talent there. And I'll actively campaign for those as they attempt to take on the role of president.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: Now, on the flip side, Michael Bennet tells "Axios," let's pull this up. If he runs, I think he'll beat Donald Trump again and I would support him in beating Donald Trump again. So, which is the winning strategy for the state of Colorado?

utterances.speaker: RILEY
utterances.utterance: Well, I - I -- he's probably not going to - to win that race. I mean I think he's got his work cut out for him. The Republican candidate in Colorado has his work cut out for him. But in some of these other states, I mean, Marie is right that - that the Trump-backed candidates may not be the best fit for that state. I mean you mentioned Ohio and Pennsylvania. We - we'll see. I mean a lot of those Trump-backed candidates have been assisted with help from Democrats in lifting their profile.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: RILEY
utterances.utterance: But perhaps those states aren't the best fit for some of those candidates. In other states it could be a different story. It's really going to be a state-by-state issue. But I think - so you have to look at what's going on locally. I mean you mentioned -- you were talking about Alaska earlier and Palin. I think it's an interesting case there because this sort of Republican populism that culminated with the election of Donald Trump sort of started arguably with Sarah Palin. And the question is whether that - that - that movement has legs without - without a Donald Trump at the top of the ticket.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: Jason -- excuse me, Jonathan -- Jason, hold it right there. Jonathan, I want to make sure we get you in there. We have a hard stop in a minute. Twitter promising once again, you know, they've got this grand plan to prevent the spread of information ahead of the midterms. It's kind of the elephant in the room when we talk about all the candidates. Is there any hope that they're actually going to get anything right this time?

utterances.speaker: TURLEY
utterances.utterance: No. I mean Twitter is a habitual offender of free speech. And so saying, trust us, we're Twitter, is not going to go over very well. You have the CEO say, it's not a question of who should speak but who should be heard.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: TURLEY
utterances.utterance: Well, that's a corporate philosophy. They just banned someone for talking about the raid. A columnist for talking about the Mar-a-Lago raid. Every indication is that Twitter is going to follow its pattern. And that is a pattern of censorship.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: Panel, we've got to leave it there, but thanks so much. We'll see you next Sunday. We're getting a rare look next inside the Washington, D.C., Temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints. The temple, for the first time, opening its doors to the public in 50 years. FOX NEWS SUNDAY got a tour with Senator Mitt Romney to talk about its significance to the Mormon congregation across the country.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: Well, just outside Washington, D.C., is a majestic and mysterious looking landmark, a temple that's well-known to everyone inside the beltway but that very, very few people have set foot inside. If you've traveled here, you really can't miss it. The white and gold spires rise high above the surrounding forest and highways. Today, leaders will rededicate that space following a multiyear renovation. First, though, the public, including Fox News, is given a very rare glimpse inside.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: Towering over the beltway, the Washington, D.C., temple is an iconic part of the Maryland skyline. With a striking Alabama white marble exterior, six spires, and an 18-foot tall sculpture of the Angel Moroni. In 1974, it became the first temple built on the East Coast and is still one of the largest in the world. At its dedication, a week of VIP tours included President Gerald Ford and First Lady Betty Ford. In 2018, it closed for two years of renovation, but Covid delayed the reopening until now.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: We have been waiting so long for this opportunity, and we're so glad that you are here with us.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: Only members of the church can enter. But to celebrate the rededication, the church opened its doors to the public for the first time in half a century. Inside, it's a series of intimate rooms and spaces where members of the faith gather for sacred ceremonies, like baptisms and marriages. Even simply for quiet, private reflection.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: The temple is a holy place and a sacred space. It's a point of intersection between our life here on earth and eternity.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: The public tours once again drew visitors and dignitaries from across Washington, including Utah Senator Mitt Romney, who brought his Senate colleagues with him.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: Earlier, Bret Baier sat down with Senator Mitt Romney at the temple to talk about what it means to him as a Mormon and how his faith has impacted his many decades of public service.

utterances.speaker: BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: Senator, thanks for the time.

utterances.speaker: SEN. MITT ROMNEY (R-UT)
utterances.utterance: Thanks, Bret. Good to be with you.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: In the shadow of this magnificent building, it's really quite something as you look at it. You know, you drive down the Capitol beltway and there it is. It's spectacular.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: I remember the first time I came here. I was on a bus with my family and friends from Boston. And people told us that we wouldn't miss it. Don't worry, you'll - you'll see it. And we wondered. We kept on looking out the window, left and right, where is it. Is it there? And then suddenly, there's this beautiful white building. It looks like it was in the middle of the road. It's quite majestic.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: For someone who doesn't get it, this means a lot to you and your faith.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: There's no question. This - this building is a place where most members of my faith, if they want to be married forever, not just here on earth, not death till your part, but forever, this is where they'll come to have their - their marriage made permanent. We call it sealing (ph), putting together forever a family. And that's the highest ordinance which occurs in this building.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: You know, you've spoken out numerous times throughout your political career about how much your faith means to you. A big speech back in 2007 where you addressed it head on and you said it's really your center, your heart.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: I learned from my parents and from my faith the values which have, if you will, guided my life. I've not always been entirely true to them. Sometimes I've straight and come back. But - but I have - I have been devoted to the - the principles taught by my faith and my family. That doesn't guide your politics necessarily, but it does guide how you interact with other people. It guides the degree of honesty you have, the vision you have for the future, the things you hope for. And -- and, of course, it's been a defining part of my life.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: For other religions, they look at - at the Mormon faith and -and have questions and there's all this kind of intrigue about it. But the basic thing that you talked about was the principles that you - you live by.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: When I ran for office, I pointed out that we don't choose presidents or elected offices anywhere based upon the religion of the person who's running. But, nonetheless, we look at their religious foundation to understand whether they will share our values, whether they'll believe in honesty and integrity, family. And those things, I think, are -- are central to my faith and to other faiths. I love the fact that America is a religious nation, and that people have a conviction that there's something more important than just themselves and their own selfishness. They think there's a purpose and great significance.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: You know, you've had some tough votes in Washington. And one of them, obviously, was the impeachment vote. CHRIS WALLACE (FOX NEWS SUNDAY, 2020): Do believe that Donald Trump is unfit to serve as president and should be removed from office? ROMNEY (FOX NEWS SUNDAY, 2020): I do believe he should be removed from office. That's the vote that I will take in just a short while.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.utterance: You realize this is war. Donald Trump will never forgive you for this.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: There's a - there's a hymn that is sung in my church. It's an old protestant him, which is, do what is right, let the consequence follow. I know in my heart that I'm doing what's right. I understand there's going to be enormous consequence.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Do what is right, let the consequence follow.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: Tat little phrase has certainly connected for me throughout my life, which is, try and do what's right, don't worry so much about what it means for your re-election or for your promotion or for how much money you're going to get. Do what you believe is right. And that's a reminder, I think, that is important for all of us.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Yes. So it's grounding for you when you're up on Capitol Hill dealing with all of the stuff day-to-day?

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: The values that you have, the fundamental principles that guide your life of integrity and honesty, of recognizing that other people are also children of God, that all people are children of God, black, white, gay, straight, we're all God's children, those kind of principles, I think, are an important part of both politics, as well as everyday living.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: You've got a big family.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: I do!

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: How they doing?

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: I've got 25 grandkids. And we just had our first great grandchild. So it looks like there's going to be no end to the propagation of Romneys.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: The expanding Romneys.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: And they take this in the same light? I mean, have you pass that onto them?

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: Well, it's an important part of my job, I think, as a grandfather now, to - to share with my grandchildren, if you will, the family legacy. And there are really three elements to our family legacy. Number one is our commitment to the family, the caring for one another. Number two is our commitment to faith, our conviction that God lives and that Jesus Christ is his son. And, number three is kindness.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: But for somebody who looks at that and says, how can they be that good?

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: We're not. There have been times in my life when I have strayed from being 100 percent accurate or 100 percent honest, when I've done things for advantage or politics. And I look back on those things now with great regret. And - and so I say at this stage in my life, I'm not doing that anymore. I'm going to be straight and honest to the extent I humanly can and I'm not going to worry about what the consequence might be for me politically or otherwise.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: In an age of social media where it can get dark sometimes.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: It's tough to pull out of that.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: I wonder how people who read the comments actually make it day-to- day. I don't know that I've ever read comments on Twitter. I - I follow Twitter pretty carefully to see what's going on. I - I find, you know, getting instant news is - is interesting and compelling and helps me do my job. But - but reading comments people have about things I might say, look, I recognize a lot of this is just bots coming from the Chinese and the Russians, others just coming from disaffected people. Others from, if you will, the person that's living in the basement of their parents' house. I really don't need to worry about those folks. I remember, when I was running for governor in Massachusetts, my advisor, Mike Murphy, said to me, look, I'll help you in your campaign and you can watch TV has much as you'd like and see what's going on in the campaign, but you can't read the papers. And I said -- about yourself. I said, why is that? And he said, if you read an article about yourself, you will inevitably start in your next address addressing what was in that article. It may have been written by a 25-year-old young person, it may have been off the mark, but you're going to be influenced by it. And so, likewise, reading social media comments, you don't want to do that and be influenced by it.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: Just do what's right and let the consequence follow.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Not to get too political, but there's a lot of threats that we face as a country, but the social fabric and keeping that together and families that - that your religion and faith talk about a lot. Where - where do you see that threat for the country?

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: The founders of my religion and the leaders of my religion have long said that our Constitution was inspired. And, of course, the freedom of religion being central to our Constitution. And so I think, at the same time, we believe that having people who recognize that one another are not just citizens, fellow citizens, but also fellow children of God, that we're in the same human family, helps bring the temperature down.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: You know, when you were running for president, you made a point to make this speech about your faith. Why did you think it was important? ROMNEY (2007): I will serve no one religion, no one group, no one cause and no one interest. A president must serve only the common cause of the people of the United States.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: John F. Kennedy, who when he ran people wondered, hey, can we elect a Catholic president? JOHN F. KENNEDY, FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT (1960): I am not the Catholic candidate for president. I am the Democratic Party's candidate for president.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: I mean today we chuckle at that, but back then it was a question. And he pointed out that the Constitution made it clear that religious liberty was part of the American experience and that there would never be a religious test or someone seeking political office. And that was exactly the case in my circumstance as well. I want to remind people there's not a religious test. You may not agree with my faith, you may not think this is the most beautiful building in Washington, D.C., as I do, but, nonetheless, you allow people of different faiths to serve in office as long as they make their oath of office their primary responsibility and they hue to it in a way that does not vary.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Last thing, I mean, your family's been through a lot, been through a lot of races. They're still into this politics thing?

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: I'd much rather spend time here than in the Capitol Building. But politics is exciting and there's - there's great work to be done. The country faces some enormous challenges, but good people of all faiths can come together and hopefully address those challenges to keep America the hope of the earth.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Senator, thanks for the time.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.utterance: Thanks, Bret.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: Bret Baier bringing us an exclusive interview. Thank you. Up next, final word on the new anchor of this program.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: That does it for us today. I'm Gillian Turner. But before we go, you may have heard, my wonderful colleague and tremendous journalist, Shannon Bream, will take over this chair permanently next month. She is just the third person to anchor this program in its illustrious 26-year history. She follows in the footsteps of Tony Snow and Chris Wallace. Shannon will continue in her role as Fox News chief legal correspondent as well. But now, every Sunday, you'll see her right here beginning September 11th. Until then, you can find Shannon weeknights on Fox News Channel anchoring "Fox News At Night." Shannon, congratulations from all of us here in the Washington bureau and at Fox News. We cannot wait to cheer you on. To everyone at home, have a great day. We'll see you next FOX NEWS SUNDAY.
